posts.title: Math test
posts.text: Math test This a math test Introduction In supervised learning, we often use parametric models p(y∣X,θ)p(\mathbf{y} \lvert \mathbf{X},\boldsymbol\theta)p(y∣X,θ) to explain data and infer optimal values of parameter θ\boldsymbol\thetaθ via maximum likelihood or maximum a posteriori estimation. If needed we can also infer a full posterior distribution p(θ∣X,y)p(\boldsymbol\theta \lvert \mathbf{X},\mathbf{y})p(θ∣X,y) instead of a point estimate θ^\boldsymbol{\hat\theta}θ^. With increasing data complexity, models with a higher number of parameters are usually needed to explain data reasonably well. Methods that use models with a fixed number of parameters are called parametric methods. In non-parametric methods, on the other hand, the number of parameters depend on the dataset size. For example, in Nadaraya-Watson kernel regression, a weight wiw_iwi​ is assigned to each observed target yiy_iyi​ and for predicting the target value at a new point x\mathbf{x}x a weighted average is computed: f(x)=∑i=1Nwi(x)yif(\mathbf{x}) = \sum_{i=1}^{N}w_i(\mathbf{x})y_i f(x)=i=1∑N​wi​(x)yi​ wi(x)=κ(x,xi)∑i′=1Nκ(x,xi′)w_i(\mathbf{x}) = \frac{\kappa(\mathbf{x}, \mathbf{x}_{i})}{\sum_{i'=1}^{N}\kappa(\mathbf{x}, \mathbf{x}_{i'})} wi​(x)=∑i′=1N​κ(x,xi′​)κ(x,xi​)​

posts.title: Hello World
posts.text: Welcome to Hexo! This is your very first post. Check documentation for more info. If you get any problems when using Hexo, you can find the answer in troubleshooting or you can ask me on GitHub. Quick Start Create a new post 1$ hexo new "My New Post" More info: Writing Run server 1$ hexo server More info: Server Generate static files 1$ hexo generate More info: Generating Deploy to remote sites 1$ hexo deploy More info: Deployment
